newsitem.title: GERMANY: F.O. LICHT - Daily sugar report.
newsitem.headline: F.O. LICHT - Daily sugar report.

text.p: The following is a direct contribution from statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.

White sugar futures in London closed slightly weaker in quiet trade. The spot March contract lost $0.80 to close at $297.25 per tonne, while May gave up $0.60 to close at $297.15 per tonne. The March white/raw premium narrowed slightly to around $69 per tonne and with the generally bearish sentiment in London, more selling is widely expected on the whites to drag it down further.

In New York raw sugar futures settled firmer in a consolidation to recent losses. Amid a continued dearth of physical offtake, ample supplies and a bearish technical outlook, March futures are seen continuing to descend toward 10 cents/lb.

GERMANY - Sugar content notched up 1 percentage point in the week ended December 6 to reach 18.19 per cent against 16.74 per cent in 1995 and 17.15 per cent in 1994. This gain offset lower beet deliveries in the week under review which amounted to 2.153 million tonnes against 2.272 million tonnes in 1995.

The estimate for the total amount of beet processed in 1996 has been reduced by the German Sugar Association to 25.794 million tonnes against 25.798 million tonnes before. Total sugar production in the week ended December 6 reached 382,435 tonnes, raw value, against 363,757 tonnes in the like period the previous year.
This brought cumulative production so far in 1996 up to 4.002 million tonnes compared to 3.689 million tonnes in 1995 and 3.775 million tonnes in 1994.

BELGIUM - Sugar imports in July 1996 amounted to 10,707 tonnes, raw value, sharply down from last year's 119,303 tonnes. This brought cumulative imports in the first ten months of 1995/96 (October/July) up to 634,672 tonnes against 1.027 million tonnes in 1994/95. Total imports in 1994/95 amounted to 1.139 million tonnes compared to 663,985 tonnes in 1993/94.

Major countries of origin in October/July 1995/96 were France with 468,989 tonnes whites against 847,092 tonnes, Germany with 66,795 tonnes compared to 68,103 tonnes and the Netherlands with 39,509 tonnes, up from 12,686 tonnes. Sugar exports in July 1996 amounted to 44,707 tonnes, down from last year's 115,322 tonnes.

This brought cumulative exports in October/July 1995/96 up to 930,509 tonnes, down from 1.461 million tonnes in 1994/95. Total exports in 1994/95 amounted to 1.566 million tonnes against 1.337 million tonnes in 1993/94 and 962,231 tonnes in 1992/93. Major countries of destination in 1995/96 were Syria with 138,697 tonnes compared to 121,106 tonnes and Turkey with 109,196 tonnes against 123,838 tonnes.

FINLAND - Sugar imports in August 1996 amounted to 18,388 tonnes, raw value, against negligible amounts in August 1995. This brought cumulative imports in the first eleven months of 1995/96 (October/August) up to 43,113 tonnes, down from 51,916 tonnes in the like period the previous year.

Total imports in 1994/95 reached 52,647 tonnes against 116,817 tonnes in 1993/94. Major countries of origin in 1995/96 were Guyana with 10,326 tonnes raws against nil, St. Christopher-Nevis with 9,820 tonnes against nil and Zimbabwe with 8,222 tonnes against nil.

Sugar exports in August 1996 amounted to 4,054 tonnes which brought cumulative exports in October/August 1995/96 up to 43,945 tonnes against 6,654 tonnes in the corresponding period the previous year.

Total exports in 1994/95 reached 6,763 tonnes against 15,127 tonnes in 1993/94. Major countries of destination in 1995/96 were Uzbekistan with 11,795 tonnes whites against nil and Estonia with 11,381 tonnes compared to 754 tonnes.

Pakistan bought 51,000 tonnes of crystal white sugar for shipment by the end of December 1996, as a result of its recent buying tender. The sugar will arrive in Pakistan by rail at a reported price of $360 per tonne c&f basis and is split into two consignments of 37,500 and 13,500 tonnes, it was said. Details of suppliers have yet to emerge.
